text:
Hello Superpath community!

We have a new "Dear Superpath" question. This is a way for folks to ask anonyous questions. 

Career stage: mid (4-7 years of experience)

"Are you less likely to hire a person to your team if they have a Slavic name?"

Hello Superpath community!

We have a new "Dear Superpath" question. This is a way for folks to ask anonyous questions. 

Career stage: junior (1-3 years of experience)

"Seeking interview advice for someone with a non-traditional background.

I've taken a very non-traditional path with my career. No college degree (Ivy League dropout if that means anything), spent most of my twenties traveling and working in restaurants. Didn't become career-focused until 30, but have taken it very seriously since (34 now). Taught myself SEO, copywriting, web design, and social media marketing all pretty darn well! I've got a dozen live projects throughout the web I can show as proof of skill set and self-motivation. 

I've gussied up my resume, linkedin, and public profiles to highlight my projects and skills, and often have no problem getting -to- the initial interview, but inevitably that's when they want to know my background and start to see red flags. 

Perhaps this is my own insecurity, but I feel the lack of a degree and very little white collar work experience (despite being 34) really throws people off. 

I'm very confident I've got what it takes to help a great company. How can I help them get past their biases to give me a chance? 

Thanks for your time. Grateful I could post this anonymously because I'm dealing with serious imposter syndrome in these professional groups!"

"Are you less likely to hire a person to your team if they have a Slavic name?"

Last names wouldn't factor into my hiring process whatsoever.

elements.text:
"Are you less likely to hire a person to your team if they have a Slavic name?"

Last names wouldn't factor into my hiring process whatsoever.

text:
This story only makes me want to hire you MORE, not less. Spent your vibrant youth living, not subscribing to the rat race. Then, in 4 short years, self-taught yourself up in an in-demand field.

I'd maybe aim to try and find hiring teams that are closer to your age (I'm your age, btw). The idea that this story "throws people off" feels WILDLY outdated to me. You gotta be like 50+ to hum and haw over a "gap in the resume" and such.

As for impostor syndrome: please understand that no one fucking knows what they're doing, really. I've worked with tons of people who flailingly failed upwards, engineer savants who couldn't break into the market, 21-yr old entrepreneurial breakout successes who just lucked into a celeb endorsement... the idea that there's this narrow path of "career success" that you must carefully navigate is complete fiction. Show up, deliver value, understand why do you what you do with conviction... you'll be fine.

Good luck! :heart:
